title: 893: How to Jumpstart Your Data Career (by Applying Like a Scientist) â€” with Avery Smith

rawLines.text: What is the bare minimum to get someone
their first data job? It obviously
depends on like how much time you're
putting aside. If you're spending like
let's say two hours a day on average, so
like 14 hours a week, I think it's
possible to be like 100% prepared like
skill-wise in about 12 weeks. Often it
takes a while to get actually to get
hired. If you want to get like a remote
job, it's going to take you longer. If
you're able to supply a project even
beforehand or or even in the interview,
like that flips the interview on its
head where instead of them asking you
questions that are like mystery
questions, they're going to probably ask
you about your own
work. Avery, welcome to the Super Data
Science podcast. It's awesome to have
you here for this special episode.
Avery, where are you calling in from? I
am in Utah. I'm just a little bit uh
south of Salt Lake and I'm actually um
my office is a a shed. So last year I
bought a shed and I refurbished it to
have like AC and heating and everything
and really good internet and so uh I'm
I'm in a random shed in Utah basically.
Uh it looks fantastic. So for people
watching the YouTube version, it's
beautifully decorated and uh yeah, I
wish I had such a nice background for
podcasting myself. Um, it's so great to
have you on the show, Avery. You're a
big name in data science and we have a
great episode for folks, especially
folks who are looking to break into a
career in data, data analytics, data
science, maybe machine learning. And so,
let's talk about how you got into this a
bit. You left a corporate career in data
science to help working professionals
break into data science. You have an
extremely popular data career jumpstart
boot camp. We've got a link to that in
the show notes, of course. Also very
easy to find with a Google search. And
you also have the Avery Smith YouTube
channel, uh, which has lots of great
instructional videos. And after watching
your videos, it's hard not to notice
that you aim not only to teach, but to
motivate and inspire with an infectious
passion for data that's impossible not
to catch. Um, so a career change can be
daunting for folks out there that are
listening. How do you help career
changers stop waiting for permission
whether from a degree, a manager, or
their own self-doubt and start framing
their past experiences as an advantage,
not a liability? That is uh such a good
question um and super timely because I
recently just had one of my students on
on my podcast and um she landed a pretty
sweet data job. Uh and beforehand she
was like not technical. she didn't have
like a computer science or statistics
degree. Um, but a lot of people went and
looked at this person's LinkedIn and the
LinkedIn kind of looked like they had a
a lot of data experience. So, I love
what you said like how can we make our
current experience or our previous
experience look more data uh than it
might have been because data is really
everywhere. Like any sort of job you're
in, you can figure out how to how to use
data there. Um, and then the other thing
is like in terms of like motivation and
inspiration, I think the number one
hiring manager that rejects you from
jobs is yourself. Like a lot of the
times we're we are our own worst
self-critics. Uh, and if we can get past
the mentality of like, oh, I have to be
perfect to land a data job, to deserve a
data job, to be qualified for one, as
soon as we get that out of our mind, I I
feel like it enables us to actually
relax and feel good about ourselves and
land our our first data job or get
promoted or whatever. So, um, I do think
that there is a lot of like mindset that
people can practice to to help them in
their data careers. Nice. Yeah, that's
great guidance. I agree with it 100%. It
is super easy. And it's also it's
interesting. I I've read research that
some some sociodemographic groups are
more likely to doubt themselves. Uh so
apparently white men for example are
least likely. And so that for example,
it leads to so many white men picking up
podcast microphones and starting
podcasts uh probably as well because
there's so many of us out there that are
like my I've really got something that
people need to hear. Um whereas uh some
other sociodemographic groups, they are
not so likely to think that, you know,
they're they really have something
important to say that they're worthy of
this opportunity. And so, for example,
I've read that uh women are more are
less likely to apply to jobs where they
don't meet every
criterion. Uh
whereas men are more likely to just be
like, ah, you know, just give it a shot.
Um and so, yeah, I don't know. There's
these interesting kinds of things there
that, you know, there there certainly
are different levels and there's
probably more variance by individual as
well, more so than by group. There's
people out there who are just more, you
know, you want to feel like you're
really well prepared. But I think in a
career like anything in data, any of
these careers, it's so fast
moving that no, no one really knows
what's going on and you really should
throw your hat in the ring. Yeah. By the
time you've like first off, I think it's
impossible to like to feel like you've
mastered really any part of data because
it's so vast, right? And there's and by
the time you've mastered anything,
there's like five other things that have
popped up uh and the old stuff has
become uh obsolete. So, it's it's
definitely one of those things where
like you you can't know it all. And once
you become comfortable not knowing it
all, but maybe you become comfortable
how to how to solve problems and how to
figure stuff out, I think that's like
where, like you said, like if you reach
maybe 50% even of requirements like yolo
just apply. Um, but that that's hard to
get to that point of of feeling feeling
that confident for for a lot of people.
And we have tons of content in this

both for the kinds of problem general
problem solving skills that you're
describing as well as specific technical

I've got lots of questions on those

let's talk more about your career

well as some more of this mindset stuff.
I've got some cool questions here that

of all, you've apparently described

like a superhero. Can you elaborate on

hydrofuloric acid incident? Your
researchers are good. I'm impressed. So
yes, um I I studied chemical engineering
in college and I was a chemical lab
technician. So I wore like the white
coat, the huge goggles, the gloves,
everything. And I was in the lab doing
experiments. Um and uh one for one
particular job I was a chemical lab
technician. We worked with like heavy
metals and uh to like basically clean
these heavy metals, we'd use
hydrofuloric acid, which is like a super
dangerous acid. Um, like it's like very
notorious for if it gets on your skin,
it like eats into your skin straight to
the bone. Uh, and one time, uh, I was
handling it and I got a little bit lazy
and, uh, I decided to only wear one
glove, the glove that I was going to be
like around the hydrofuloric acid. Uh,
but I was also not really paying
attention and I didn't realize that this
little um, vial of hydrofuloric acid was
still hot. And so when I took off the
lid and it was still warm, the pressure
changed caused it to jump and I jumped
from the vial onto my other hand and uh
I ran to the bathroom to or the the sink
as fast as I possibly could and washed
it all off. And luckily I got there
quick enough that nothing really bad
happened. But I was like, man, I got to
get out of this sucky job. Like I don't
want to be risking my life for the the
amount I'm getting paid. You want to pay
me like millions of dollars to do that,
I'm in. but you want to pay me like
minimum wage, I'm out. Uh, and so I
actually got lucky and basically the
place I was I was working at um was was
kind of like very datacentric and they
had a data scientist on staff and like
he did not work in the lab. He had his
own office with really pretty windows
with views of the mountains and he got
to just work on his computer and not
stand in the lab that was freezing all
the time and I was like, "Okay, I want
that guy's job, not my job." Um, and so
that kind of piqued my my interest and
eventually um after after a lot of
studying and effort and doing a lot of
things wrong, uh, I was able to pivot
into like a junior data analyst role at
this company. Uh, at first it was just
likeif for like 25% of the time and then
50% and then 100%. I eventually left the
lab and was just doing data and I was
like ah a computer no hydrofuloric acid
and and my life was good. That is a
really cool approach where you got to do
that incrementally that the company was
open to doing that. I actually haven't
heard of that before and that's that's
an interesting new idea for maybe any of
our listeners out there who are
currently in a non-data role but want to
be moving into one to say hey you know I
think I could provide a lot more value
for a company uh doing this kind of data
analysis or data engineering and I've
been working on evenings and weekends on
these particular courses uh you know I
did this project that was kind of
relevant I'd love to actually just be
using our company data and I know that I
don't have much experience yet just give
me a quarter of my time to do that.
Yeah, it's it's really powerful. An
internal pivot like that where you can
like become a data person within your
company in my opinion for for new people
is like for career pivoters is the best
place to go because they already know,
like, and trust you. They're they're
like, "Oh, we love John. John works hard
and does good work and so you're less of
a risk versus if you're going to leave a
company and go somewhere else, they
don't really know you and you don't
really have any data experience and so
you're more of a risk." So, if you can
do that internally, that ends up working
quite well. Um, I will say I got lucky
because I worked at a really small
company that had less than 15 people.
Uh, I think small companies are a little
bit more agile like that. I think if I
was at Exxon Mobile at the time, which I
later went on to work for, I wouldn't
have worked out so well. But I I think
an internal pivot, even if you become
just like the data guy or the data gal
on your team, that's like a really good
start. Nice. Great tip. Another thing
from that time that we picked up from
our research is that you have this power
you use, you leverage the power of
anti-goals. So you described your
motivation is driven more by not wanting
to be where I am at than by some
aspirational end state. And so how can
our listeners aspiring data
professionals use anti- goals as a
practical tool to spark change? I think
the key is just like what do humans want
in life? Right? We just want to be happy
and oftentimes it seems like we maybe
aren't happy. And so I just knew that
like I didn't want to be in the lab. I
wanted to make more money. I didn't want
to work with chemicals. It just kind of
felt like it wasn't a dead-end job, but
it just like wasn't bringing me joy. And
so, I knew I had to make a difference
because I think the average human works
like 80 to like 90,000 hours in their
lifetime. And it's just like I I
couldn't picture my future just
spending, you know, 70,000 more hours
just doing this. It wasn't it wasn't for
me. Um, so I think that's really big is
just like if you're in enough pain,
you're willing to work hard to get out
of it. I guess you mentioning the 80,000
hours reminds me of two resources that I
can share with listeners. Um, so there's
a website called 80,000 hours that uh
was created by a friend of mine uh Ben
Todd. And we actually had Ben Todd on
the show. I can quickly look up his uh

episode number 497
uh back in 2021, so almost four years

he used his this highly analytical
uh career-based approach to providing

lots of reasons why um data careers can

great episode for people to check out.
And then a book that I read recently
that was hugely influential on my
thinking. I've actually talked about it
on the show before, but it's been at
least a year since I have. There's a
book called 4,000 Weeks, which is
similar. So, 4,000 weeks is about 80,000
hours of work. Um, oh wait, no, actually
4,000 weeks is the average human
lifespan,
not your working time, but 4,000 weeks
is actually how many weeks you have in
your life, which is the point of the
book, which is that there's more to life
than work. And, you know, no amount of
optimizing your time and getting more
done is going to escape the reality that
you're on this planet for a limited time
and there's probably things you want to
be doing other than work. So, it's a
kind of it's interesting. It's a really
good book by Oliver Burkeman. I'll have
a a link to that in the show notes as
well. But very So I don't know. I'm just

there's so much to learn and you'll

you need to focus on the skills that are

for example, um, like let's say I'll try

Python's super in demand for for data

why it's fourth in the data data
learning ladder because Excel is in

pretty easy. Like most people have used
Excel one way or another in their
career. So that's why I think you should

most in demand data tool that there is.
Uh but it is a programming language, but
it's definitely easier than than Python
when you're just starting out. And then
lastly, Python because it is quite in
demand, but it's it's a lot to learn.
And so my whole philosophy is on this
like quadrant of how in demand is a
skill and how easy is it to learn. And
you want to start with the the ones that
are in demand and easy to learn and then
work your way up from
